Historic First Flights of Pan American Slippers
Dixie Slipper completes first transatlantic passenger flight
New York to Lisbon, Portugal,
June 29, 1939
Pan American's Dixie Clipper (NC18605) lands at Lisbon and becomes the first airplane to complete a
First Officers Gilbert B. Blackmore and Robert D. Fordyce and a crew of nine, departed from Port Washington,
New York, the day before, flying via the Azores with 22 passengers.
Pan American's Boeing B-314s served magnificently throughout World War II, transporting military person-
nel and supplies to the war zones as well as carrying most of the leaders of the Allied Nations to important
strategic missions on all continents.
About the Artist
In 1926, John T. McCoy became a working student for the Curtiss Flying Ser-
vice, Curtiss Field, Long Island, New York.
When Charles A. Lindbergh arrived at Curtiss Field, his SPIRIT OF ST. LOUIS
was housed in one of the Curtiss hangers. It was at this time that McCoy met
Lindbergh, who was most cordial and friendly to those who worked on the flight
line. In those days muscle power was the method used for starting engines, ac
complished by swinging the propeller by hand. McCoy often pulled a prop through
Years later, when McCoy was commissioned to do paintings depicting the
history of Pan American World Airways, Inc. - entitled HISTORIC FIRST FLIGHTS
OF PAN AMERICAN CLIPPERS - he consulted with Lindbergh on the selection of
aircraft and locations for the series.
This is one picture in a series of thirteen. If you would like to purchase 8½" x 11"
or 16" x 20" limited edition prints, send your letter of inquiry to: Public Relations
Department - Pan American World Airways, Inc., Pan Am Building, New York, New
York 10166. Please include code number 304 in your letter.

Visorio Tre Flighis of Dan Amorican Elpers
Dirio Clippor completes first transallantis passenger flight
New York to Lisbon, , Portugal,
June 29, 1939
Pan American's Dixie Clipper (NC18605) lands at Lisbon and becomes the first airplane to complete a
scheduled transatlantic passenger flight. The Boeing B.314, under command of Captain R. O. D. Sullivan with
First Officers Gilbert B. Blackmore and Robert D. Fordyce and a crew of nine, departed from Port Washington,
New York, the day before, flying via the Azores with 22 passengers.
Pan American's Boeing B•314s served magnificently throughout World War Il, transporting military person-
nel and supplies to the war zones as well as carrying most of the leaders of the Allied Nations to important
strategic missions on all continents.
Shout the Srist
In 1926, John T. McCoy became a working student for the Curtiss Flying Ser
vice, Curtiss Field, Long Island, New York.
When Charles A. Lindbergh arrived at Curtiss Field, his SPIRIT OF ST. LOUIS
was housed in one of the Curtiss hangers. It was at this time that McCoy met
Lindbergh, who was most cordial and friendly to those who worked on the flight
line. In those days muscle power was the method used for starting engines, ac
complished by swinging the propeller by hand. McCoy often pulled a prop through
for Lindbergh.
Years later, when McCoy was commissioned to do paintings depicting the
history of Pan American World Airways, Inc. - entitled HISTORIC FIRST FLIGHTS
OF PAN AMERICAN CLIPPERS - he consulted with Lindbergh on the selection of
aircraft and locations for the series.
This is one picture in a series of thirteen. If you would like to purchase 8½" × 11*
or 16" × 20" limited edition prints, send your letter of inquiry to: Public Relations
Department - Pan American World Airways, Inc., Pan Am Building, New York, New
